clinical_study.brief_title: The Treatment Effectiveness of Combined tDCs and Neurofeedback (NF) for Patients With Cognitive Deficits After Stroke
clinical_study.official_title: The Treatment Effectiveness of Combined tDCs and Neurofeedback (NF) for Patients With Cognitive Deficits After Stroke

brief_summary.textblock: This is a double blinded, randomized control trial with a pretest-posttest control and interventional groups design. Both the assessor and participants are blinded to all assessments and evaluations. All patients with subacute stroke undergo in-patient or out-patient rehabilitation are screened initially by a series of screening test. Suitable patients are assigned randomly to 3 groups respectively. Group 1 is the combined transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) and neurofeedback group. Group 2 is the neurofeedback group. Group 3 is the control group with sham neurofeedback training.

detailed_description.textblock:
Treatment sessions for all three groups are conducted by the investigators who has training in neurofeedback and transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCs). The neurofeedback protocol will follow the study of Reichert et al., 2016. Electroencephalography signals for SensoriMotor Rhythm (SMR) training were recorded at channel Cz, digitized at 256 Hertz (Hz) and filtered with a 0.5 Hz high-pass and a 60 Hz low-pass filter. 50 Hz Notch filter will be setup to eliminate the background noise. A 5-channel system amplifier (Procomp5, thought technology) would be adopted for data recording. The ground electrode was located at the right mastoid, the reference at the left mastoid. Each participant performed 10 training sessions on different days. Sessions were conducted 3-5 times a week and consisted of 10 min of preparation, a 3-min baseline trial in which the participants saw moving bars while instructed to relax themselves without trying to control the bars voluntarily, and six 3-min feedback runs. In these runs, participants were instructed to increase SMR power while reducing artifacts (EMG & EOG). Three bars were presented on a computer screen: the height of the bar in the middle reflected real-time SMR power (12-15 Hz, band power), while the height of the left bar reflected theta power (4-7 Hz, EEG band power) and the height of the right bar beta power (EEG band power between 21 and 35 Hz which indicates movements and other high-frequency disturbances). The data recorded in the baseline trial was used to calculate individual thresholds for the three bars. The threshold of SMR power was adapted automatically after each run on the basis of the previous run (mean). When the SMR band power exceeded the predefined threshold, the color of the bar changed from red to green. When participant was able to move the SMR bar above its threshold while keeping the artifact bars below the thresholds, reward was given by getting points shown at the screen. Furthermore, auditory feedback was provided as a reward by means of a midi tone feedback. Participants were not given any instruction of how to control the feedback bars but were only told to stay mentally focused and physically relaxed. Patients in all three groups will receive 30 minutes conventional computer remediation training after neurofeedback in each training session. Attention Processing Training III software was adopted for clients training. The software had categorized attention according to Sohlberg & Mateer, 1987 and divided into sustained attention, selective attention, suppression, working memory and alternate attention. The programme consisted of both visual and auditory exercises. The investigators will assign the computer remediation exercise to the clients according to the participants' abilities.
The tDCS + neurofeedback group will carry out 30 minutes tDCS simultaneously with computer remediation. The tDCS protocol is based on the work of Jo. et al., 2009 with anodal tDCS (2 milliampere (mA), 30 mins, 30 seconds ramp up and down time) applied over DLPFC which is F3 or F4 according to 10-20 system. Stimulation (2 mA, 30 minutes) will be delivered by a direct current stimulator through a pair of 35 cm2 rubber electrodes enclosed in saline-soaked sponges and affixed to the head with rubber bands. The anode will be placed at F3 and cathode will be placed at F4.
The sham neurofeedback group will conduct the sham neurofeedback training. The investigator would setup according to study done by Engelbregt et al., 2015. The investigator who supervise the client to do the neurofeedback training would not know the condition as another investigator would setup the machine before the training. The electrodes of the sham objects would be placed in the inactive slot of the recording machine. The machine will be covered by the blanket after setup so that the operating investigator will not know whether it is sham or experimental condition.

primary_outcome.measure: Change score in Trail Making Test A & B from baseline
primary_outcome.time_frame: One day before the treatment , up to 4 weeks, up to 16 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Trail Making Test is a neuropsychological test of visual attention and task switching. It consists of two parts in which the subject is instructed to connect a set of 25 dots as quickly as possible while still maintaining accuracy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change score in Executive function performance Test (EFPT) from baseline
secondary_outcome.time_frame: One day before the treatment , up to 4 weeks, up to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The Executive Function Performance Test is a performance-based assessment of executive function through observation of four Instrumental Activities of Daily Living.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change score in Functional Independence Measure (FIM) from basline
secondary_outcome.time_frame: One day before the treatment , up to 4 weeks, up to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The Functional Independence Measure instrument is a basic indicator of patient disability. FIM is used to track the changes in the functional ability of a patient during an episode of hospital rehabilitation care.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change score in Stroke Adapted 30 item version of the Sickness Impact Profile (SA - SIP 30)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: One day before the treatment , up to 4 weeks, up to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: SA-SIP 30 assesses quality of life in patients who have sustained a stroke.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change score in Stroop Test from baseline
secondary_outcome.time_frame: One day before the treatment , up to 4 weeks, up to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The Stroop Test was designed to differentiate between individuals who are non-brain damaged and individuals with brain damage.

secondary_outcome.measure: Chaneg score in Rivermead Behavioral Memory Test from baseline
secondary_outcome.time_frame: One day before the treatment , After 10 treatment sessions, 3 months follow up after 10 sessions
secondary_outcome.description: The Rivermead behavioral memory Test-II consists of 11 subtests designed to assess memory difficulties frequently encountered by patients with acquired brain damage.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change score in Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT) from baseline
secondary_outcome.time_frame: One day before the treatment , up to 4 weeks, up to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT) is a neuropsychological test used to assess capacity and rate of information processing and sustained and divided attention

arm_group.description: 30 minutes neurofeedback and 30 minutes tDCs simultaneously with computer remediation.

intervention.description: tDCs and neurofeedback and computer remediation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. First or second stroke (haemorrhagic or ischaemic) confirmed by computer axial tomography scan or magnetic resonance imaging
2. Below 16 th percentile cut off in Hong Kong Montreal - Cognitive Assessment (HK - MoCA) (range from 17-25/30).
3. Less than twelve months since onset of stroke at study entry
4. Able to follow simple command
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients with severe dysphasia (either expressive or comprehensive) which restricts communication;
2. History of other neurological disease, psychiatric disorder, or alcoholism;
3. Significant impairment in visual or auditory function
4. Any additional medical or psychological condition that would affect their ability to comply with the study protocol.
